channel.title: Xbox 360
channel.description: i dont know if this would fit here, if it doesn't let me know, however does anybody know if i can use my xbox as a computer?

item.title: Xbox 360
item.dc:creator: @doom_j doom_j
item.description:
@doom_j wrote:

Why would you waste time doing that to a system that wasn’t designed for general purpose tasks, if you want a system that has the power of a computer from 2004 then go for it. You could clean that Xbox out and modify it to hold a nice small ATX motherboard and add a nice little core i3 or i5.

Read full topic

item.title: Xbox 360
item.dc:creator: @strucker Strucker
item.description:
@strucker wrote:

[quote=“vexx1345, post:2, topic:528903”]Not unless you heavily mod/jtag it, even then I don’t think you can.[/quote]I’ve gotten here so far

en.wikipedia.org

Xbox Linux

Xbox Linux was a project that ported the Linux operating system to the Xbox video game console. Because the Xbox uses a digital signature system to prevent the public from running unsigned code, one must either use a modchip, or a softmod. Originally, modchips were the only option; however, it was later demonstrated that the TSOP chip on which the Xbox's BIOS is held may be reflashed. This way, one may flash on the "Cromwell" BIOS, which was developed legally by the Xbox Linux project. Catalyzed ...


yet its for the oldie
